The reverent father’s heart upright and without deceit,
Spirit serene and content, knowing sufficiency and forgetting greed—
This is called true abundance and prosperity,
A spring within the cauldron-vessel yet unseen.

Life and death by Heaven’s decree,
The Dao’s principle it is.
The Vermilion Pine Child spoke:
*"Heaven’s birth and death all align with Dao’s workings,
Not arbitrary motion, but the Way’s own order."*

Indeed, Heaven and Earth refine their essence into yin and yang,
Yin and yang condense their essence into the Four Seasons,
The Four Seasons disperse their essence into all things.
Heaven possesses the *qi* of the Five Phases,
Following the seasons, responding to commands,
Shifting in sequence as they unfold.

In spring and summer, the yang-harmonizing *qi* nurtures all things,
In autumn and winter, the yin-cooling *qi* prunes and slays all things—
These are the natural principles, the most equitable of Dharma.

Thus it is said:
*"Life and death by Heaven’s decree,
The Dao’s principle it is."*

Heaven and Earth are thieves of all things,
All things are thieves of humankind,
Humankind are thieves of all things.
If the three thievings are harmonized,
Then the Three Powers are at peace.

The Azure Sea Crane said:
*"Heaven and Earth steal from all things to give them birth,
Yet do not know that Heaven and Earth are stolen from in return,
As all things age and decline.
All things serve humankind for clothing and use,
Yet do not know that they steal humankind’s pride and excess.
Humankind use all things for tools and craft,
Yet do not know that they steal all things to ruin and decay."*

The Xu Zhenren said:
*"All things steal from Heaven and Earth to take form,
Yet do not know that Heaven and Earth steal from all things,
Causing them to wither and grow old.
Humankind steal from all things to gather wealth,
Yet do not know that all things steal from humankind,
Exhausting them with labor and bringing misfortune.
If one steals yet denies the Dao’s way,
This is not true thieving."*

The above three meanings,
Each steals from the other in turn—
The natural principle it is.
If humankind exhaust the principle and grasp the truth,
They align with the Dao’s thieving,
Follow what is fitting and find harmony,
Go against the principle and meet disaster.

Thus the three thievings each find their fitting place,
The Three Powers all rest in their proper roles.
Hence it is said:
*"Eat in season, and the hundred bones are at ease,
Stir the mechanism, and the myriad transformations are harmonized."*

The Shizhen Zhenren said:
*"Hence it is said,"—meaning the continuity of these truths.
First, one must know Heaven and Earth’s principle of birth and death,
Then understand the three thievings’ alignment with Dao’s workings,
If the three thievings each find their fitting place,
And the Three Powers rest in their proper roles,
Then eating in season brings ease to the hundred bones,
And stirring the mechanism brings harmony to the myriad transformations.*

The Cao Daochong said:
*"All who seek to understand life and death must first eat and drink.
The Five Grains, Five Fruits, Five Flavors—
All must be seasoned and prepared appropriately,
Consumed in measure, fitting the body’s needs.
Cooked, they nourish; raw, they harm the organs—
This is the principle of eating."*

Thus, if eating and drinking follow their proper times,
And flavors accord with their due measures,
Only then does one stay within the Dao’s center,
Without exceeding its norms—
Then the hundred bones are all in harmony,
The Five Organs are at peace,
Free from all sickness,
And longevity is extended.

Hence it is said:
*"Eat in season, and the hundred bones are at ease."*

The Zhang Zifang said:
*"All things that are foul in hue,
Are not the true *qi* of harmony.
Those foul in scent,
Are not the true *qi* of balance.
Cooking that violates proper seasoning,
Is not the fulfillment of Water and Fire’s work.
What is produced out of season,
Is not the complete essence of life’s *qi*."*

The Sage warns against these four transgressions,
Thus the *Inner Classic* states:
*"Eat and drink with moderation,
Rest and rise with regularity,
Do not labor excessively or without purpose—
This is called knowing the Dao."*

Hence the virtuous person drinks the Heavenly Harmony to moisten the spirit,
And eats the Earth’s Virtue to nourish the form.

The Cui Minggong said:
*"The *Dao Classic* speaks:
'While all others possess it,
I alone am dull and coarse,
Yet I alone differ from others,
And value seeking food from the Mother.'
This is the profound meaning of eating in season."*

Eating in season brings ease to the hundred bones—
This is the application of the human Dao.
Stirring the mechanism brings harmony to the myriad transformations—
This is the essence of Heaven’s Dao.

Zhang Zifang’s hymn reads:
*"The three thievings in turn give and take,
Eating in season brings harmony to the hundred bones.
Gold and sand nourish the Five Organs like wind and rain,
Yet do not obstruct the Imperial House’s noble station."*

The Zhongli Zhenren’s *Manlu Hua* states:
*"All have the Dao within,
Yet the lost do not know its source.
Life and death by Heaven’s decree,
A marvel hidden in the mysterious pivot of the stars and constellations,
The shadow and movement shifting with each season.
With a tranquil heart, forgetting love and desire,
Adjusting the spirit in proper sequence—
Awakened wisdom, clear nature, the soul’s roundness.
If the Three Powers and the three thievings find their fitting place,
Then wealth for the nation is no difficulty.
Eating in season brings ease to the hundred bones,
Refining the elixir field.
No hindrance from the marketplace,
No obstruction in serving as court official.
Endless as the embryo’s breath,
The *qi* nourishes the infant—
Let the tortoise and hare go their way.
Humankind know their spirit when it is active,
Yet do not know the spirit’s stillness,
Nor the source of its vitality."*

The Cui Minggong said:
*"To rely solely on cleverness brings failure,
To rely solely on dullness brings confusion.
One clear, one dim—
This is called yin and yang.
One yin, one yang—
The Dao’s principle it is."*

The Lü Zhenren said:
*"Commoners take thunderous might and dazzling display as spirit,
The Sage takes boundless void and quiet stillness as the Dao.
The Dao is spirit.
Yet when one encounters the awe of lightning and thunder,
Or the fury of wind and rain,
The heart trembles in fear and calls it spirit—
They do not know that Heaven, Earth, and all things arise from this very void and stillness,
This is the spirit’s stillness,
The source of its vitality."*

The Zhongli said:
*"Spirit is subtle yet without form,
The unfathomable interplay of yin and yang.
Yet they know only that all things grow from yin and yang,
And do not know that yin and yang themselves arise from the spirit’s stillness.
The spirit’s stillness is the ultimate Dao.
Void and stillness are the Way of non-action.
Thus it is called the spirit’s stillness.
Within this stillness, yin and yang, sun and moon, the Three Powers, and all things are born—
This is the spirit’s stillness,
The source of its vitality."*

The Zifang said:
*"The Dao is ever non-acting yet nothing remains undone,
For its non-action is the true Dao.
Thus boundless and dark,
Yet within it lies essence.
Faint and indistinct,
Yet within it lies substance.
This is the ultimate Dao.
Within the spirit’s stillness lies the principle of the most profound spirit."*

Zhang Zifang’s hymn reads:
*"All know the spirit when it is active,
Yet the spirit flees and scatters like wind and cloud.
The spirit’s stillness brings natural transformation,
Prolonging life’s joy—
Only then does one know the Great Dao returns to its root."*

chunks.original_text: 赤松子《小重山》云：壤壤垓垓利与名，竭聪倾智力漫营营。 摇精损炁败元神，形神善，财命两谁亲。 大道坦然平，无为为妙用，用为昏。 查冥之内隐神精，除玄览，方始见圆明。 日月有数，大小有定。 圣功生焉，神明出焉。 锺离曰：日月，阴阳之精华，六合之中，为至尊也。 积日为月，积月为岁，行历周天，各有度数； 昃进退，亦有大小。 此则日月有数，大小有定也。 吕真人曰：日月相推而明生，寒暑相推而岁成。 有温凉寒暑、春夏秋冬，则天地长养。 万物皆因此道造化生成，岂不为圣功神明乎？ 许真人曰：凡胎卵湿化金石草木、天地万物生育之理，皆从无入有，功乃显着。 世间万物皆禀此圣功而生。 故大与小咸有定分，不相逾越，则大不轻小，小不羡大，是以鹏鴳各自逍遥，不相健羡也。 刘海蟾曰：见乃谓之象，形乃谓之器。 以象言者，日月也； 以形言者，大小也。 有象然后有数，故曰日月相数； 有形然后有位，故曰大小有定。 人为三才之灵，法阴阳升降之宜，则日月运行之数圣功满足，神登太虚，修证在人，高卑随行者也。 曹真人颂曰：日月升沉数，乾坤变易爻。 圣功神自去，大小悉安巢。 韩信甘超胯，陶潜愧折腰。 浮华与清淡，鹏鴳各逍遥。 张子房颂曰：长天日月数难藏、坤岭初交始见光。 造化只凭弦望得，神功功积镇茫茫。 施真人《满庭芳》云：真汞真砂天庭至宝，事须着意存收。 五行全处，婴姹两绸缪。 数倚三天二地，阴阳会，九六同舟。 精华媾，温温鼎器，无漏理深幽。 刚柔，分卦象，调媒火侯，方便连留。 待圣功功毕，国富民优。 变易离虚坎满，纯阳就、则有归头。 神明出，高卑有定，随行列仙俦。 其盗机也，天下莫能见，莫能知。 君子得之固躬，小人得之轻命。 许真人曰：此重举上文三盗之义。 凡盗必合其道，不可非道而盗也。 天有时，地有利，吾乘天地之时利，山泽之产育以生吾，木植吾家，如作田之类，孰不为盗耶？ 然如是也，人皆不知盗机之理。 君子小人志炁不同，君子得之委分固躬，小人得之强谋轻命。 刘海蟾曰：君子知至道之中包含万善，所求以和，所习以善，凡所运动皆设善机，与道合契，乃至精思守一，窃其微妙以资其性，或盗神水华池、玉英金液以政神仙。 贤人君子知此妙道之机，故曰：君子得之固躬。 小人即窥弄其机，乃轻其命，恒习恶行，恒蓄巧机，但务营求金帛，不念艰辛。 或修学武艺，岂辞疲倦？ 饰情巧智以求生於浮华之机，所以烦兵毒武则军旅败亡，望贵攀高则荣消辱至，或贪婪损己，或财色祸生。 虽然，最得荣华，不免其咎患。 盖为不知妙道之机，以至於此。 故曰：小人得之轻命也。 葛仙翁曰：至道无形，故天下莫能见，妙机无数，故天下莫能知理於贤人，故君子得之固躬。 乱於不肖，故小人得之轻命。 葛仙翁颂曰； 贤人穷理合虚无，得悟乾坤造化炉。 下士只争名与利，郊原丘冢是前途。 吕真人《行香子》云：妙道玄微，达者人希，任聪明、难见难知。 杳冥公主，恍惚容仪。 隐真精，藏物象，号天机。 大人穷理，秘守三奇，下愚夫逐景昏迷。 贪婪财色，举动非为。 丧精神轻，性命可，来痴施。 真人《诉衷情》云：大人君子性和平，不与物为争。

The **Master of Red Pine’s** *"Little Chongshan"* speaks:
*"Endless striving for profit and fame,
Exhausting ears and mind in vain pursuit—
Draining vital essence, depleting *qi*, harming the original spirit,
When the form and spirit are harmonized, wealth and life abandon none.
The Great Dao is vast and level,
Non-action as its wondrous function—
Yet action brings delusion.
Within the dark void, the spirit’s essence hides;
Remove the mysterious and obscure,
Only then does the radiant clarity appear.

The sun and moon have their measures,
Great and small have their fixed bounds.
From this arises the Sage’s work,
From this emerges divine luminosity."*

**Zhongli** said:
*"The sun and moon are the essence of yin and yang,
The most exalted within the Six Directions.
Days accumulate into months, months into years,
Circulating through the celestial sphere, each with its degrees—
Rising and setting, great and small.
Thus it is that the sun and moon have their measures,
And great and small have their fixed bounds."*

**Master Lü** said:
*"The sun and moon push each other, and light is born;
Cold and heat push each other, and the year is complete.
With warmth and coolness, cold and heat,
Spring, summer, autumn, and winter—
Thus Heaven and Earth nurture eternally.
All things are thereby created and born through this Dao.
Is it not the Sage’s work and divine luminosity?"*

**Master Xu** said:
*"All things—whether born from egg, womb, moisture, or transformed into metal, stone, grass, or wood—
The principles by which Heaven and Earth nurture all things
All arise from the void to the manifest.
Thus the Sage’s work is manifest.
All things in the world receive this Sage’s work and are born.
Therefore, great and small each have their fixed portion,
Neither overstepping nor envying.
Thus the great does not despise the small,
Nor the small covet the great—
Hence the *Peng* and the *Yuan* each soar freely, unburdened by comparison."*

**Master Liu Haichan** said:
*"What is seen is called *xiàng* [form],
What is shaped is called *qi* [instrument].
Speaking of *xiàng*, it is the sun and moon;
Speaking of *qi*, it is great and small.
Only when there is *xiàng* does number arise—
Thus, the sun and moon have their measures;
Only when there is *qi* does position arise—
Thus, great and small have their fixed bounds.
As the most refined of the Three Powers,
Conforming to the proper rise and fall of yin and yang,
The sun and moon’s movements fulfill the Sage’s work,
The spirit ascends to the Great Void—
Cultivation and verification lie within humanity,
High and low follow their course."*

**Master Cao’s** hymn:
*"The sun and moon rise and set by measure,
The *Guan* and *Kun* shift by the *yao* [trigram].
The Sage’s work departs of its own accord,
Great and small each find their resting place.
Han Xin crossed his thighs in humiliation,
Tao Qian bowed in shame at forced service.
Floating vanity and pure simplicity—
The *Peng* and *Yuan* each soar freely."*

**Master Zhang’s** hymn:
*"The boundless sky hides the sun and moon’s measure,
The *Kun* peaks first exchange their light.
Creation depends on the *xian* [celestial string] for sight,
The divine function accumulates—endless and vast."*

**Master Shi’s** *"Mantingfang"*:
*"True cinnabar, true sand—Heaven’s supreme treasure,
Must be carefully nurtured and preserved.
When the Five Phases are complete,
The *ying* and *zhi* intertwine.
Leaning on the Three Heavens and Two Earths,
Yin and yang unite, the Nine and Six in one vessel.
The essence merges, warm and gentle in the crucible,
Deep and flawless in its principle.
Hard and soft divide the *gua* [trigram] symbols,
Adjusting the mediating fire’s timing,
Using expedient means to retain.
When the Sage’s work is complete,
The nation prospers, the people thrive.
The *li* [hexagram] transforms from *Xu* to *Kan* to *Man*,
Pure yang returns—then there is a head.
Divine luminosity emerges,
High and low have their fixed ranks,
Following the ranks of the immortals.
Its mechanism is stolen—
None in the world can see it,
None can know it.
The gentleman who attains it preserves his life,
The petty man who attains it risks his fate."*

**Master Xu** said:
*"This repeats the meaning of the three thieves from earlier.
All theft must align with the Dao;
One cannot steal against the Dao.
Heaven has its seasons, Earth has its advantages.
I ride the seasons and advantages of Heaven and Earth,
Mountains and marshes nurture me—
Trees grow in my courtyard, like tilling fields.
Who does not steal?
Yet people do not know the mechanism of theft.
The gentleman and petty man differ in their intentions—
The gentleman attains it and preserves his life,
The petty man attains it and risks his fate."*

**Master Liu Haichan** said:
*"The gentleman knows that within the ultimate Dao lie all virtues.
What he seeks is harmonious,
What he practices is virtuous.
All his movements set virtuous mechanisms,
Aligned with the Dao’s patterns.
Through profound reflection and guarding the One,
He steals the subtle mysteries to nourish his nature,
Or plunders the spirit’s waters, the *Yingzi* Pool’s jade essence,
The golden liquid of immortality.
The worthy gentleman knows this wondrous mechanism,
Thus it is said: *The gentleman attains it and preserves his life.*
The petty man, glimpsing its tricks,
Lights his fate—
Ever habituated to evil deeds,
Ever scheming with cunning,
Only seeking wealth and jade,
Unmindful of toil.
Or practicing martial arts—
Would he shun fatigue?
Adorning himself with clever schemes to survive in the world’s vanity,
Thus wars and poisons arise, armies perish,
Chasing nobility leads to disgrace,
Greed harms oneself, lust brings calamity.
Though they gain glory, they cannot escape blame.
Truly, they do not know the Dao’s wondrous mechanism—
Thus it is said: *The petty man attains it and risks his fate.*"*

**Master Ge Xianweng** said:
*"The ultimate Dao is formless—
Thus none in the world can see it.
Its wondrous mechanism is boundless—
Thus none in the world can know its principle.
The worthy attain it and preserve their life,
The unworthy are ruined by it—
Thus the petty man attains it and risks his fate."*

**Master Ge Xianweng’s** hymn:
*"The worthy exhaust principles, merging with the void,
Awakening to the *Guan* and *Kun*’s alchemical furnace.
The petty scholar only contends for name and gain—
The fields and graves are their destined path."*

**Master Lü’s** *"Xingxiangzi"*:
*"The wondrous Dao is profound and subtle,
Few can attain it—
Even the brightest minds find it hard to see or know.
Dark and obscure, the sovereign’s essence,
Faint and indistinct, its form.
It hides true essence, conceals its symbols,
Called the Heavenly mechanism.
The worthy exhaust principles,
Secretly guarding the Three Wonders,
While the foolish chase illusions, lost in delusion.
Greedy for wealth and lust,
Their actions are not virtuous.
They squander their spirit lightly,
Their life and fate—
Foolishly applied."*

**The True Person’s** *"Su Zhongqing"*:
*"The noble gentleman’s nature is peaceful,
Not contending with things."*

Faintly and deeply concealed,

**The Yellow Emperor’s *Yinshu Jing* (Collected Commentaries, Middle and Lower Volumes):**
*The Yellow Emperor, Red Pine Child, Zhang Liang the True Person,
The Left Daoist of the Great Extremes, Terence Kang,
The True Person of Western Mountain, Zhongli Quan the True Person of Rectified Yang,
Lü Yan the True Person of Pure Yang, the True Person of Hua yang,

Liu Xuanying the True Person of the Sea Tortoise,
Cao Daochong the True Person of Clear and Empty.*

**Chapter on *Qiangbing* (Strong Arms) and *Yanshu* (Victorious Arts):**
*Zhongli the True Person said:*
*'Strong' refers to vigor and health;
*'Arms' denotes the tools for warding off barbarians.*

*The *De Jing* states:*
*'To nurture life is auspicious;
To direct *qi* with the heart is strength.'*
*The *I Ching* declares:*
*'The movements of Heaven are vigorous—
The noble gentleman strengthens himself and never rests.'*

*This speaks of embodying Heaven’s pure yang virtue,
Commanding all living beings,
With the heart as sovereign and *qi* as the army—
The ruler acts without action,
And all is governed.
This is the Dao of serene stillness and non-action.*

*To subdue demons with the Dao,
None shall fail.*

*Thus it is said:*
*'Strong arms, victorious arts.'*

**Master Lü’s** words:
*'The Sage establishes laws,
Intending only to suppress evil and restore order,
To govern the state and bring peace to the people.
How could it be for scheming with stratagems,
Discussing martial arts and raising armies,
Driving living beings to toil,
Slaughtering lives and gathering misfortune,
Accumulating sins and bringing calamity to descendants?
Even as Sun, Wu, Han, and Bai
Employed cunning and deceitful schemes,
Their bones became hills, their blood rivers,
Leaving all living beings in endless suffering,
And rulers with countless worries—
Could this be called great merit or broad vision?
Hence the *Five Thousand Words* says:*
*"To govern with wisdom is the thief of the state;
Not to govern with wisdom is the state’s blessing."*
*And again:*
*"Fine arms are not auspicious instruments."*

*Therefore, the *Yinshu* places this in the lower section.*

**Master Shi’s** praise:
*"To act well without trace is called strong arms;
To repel invaders and dispel barbarians is the essence of arms.
To forget the self when facing adversity is victory;
Thus, how should one cultivate and govern to secure peace and honor?"*

**Master Cao’s** *"Qingxiao Yue"*:
*"The heart as sovereign, *qi* as general—
The army of kindness as banners, wisdom as encampments.
Discipline and rhythm set the plans,
Righteousness and benevolence as armor—
Frugality and reverence as provisions,
Virtue ensuring tranquility.
Temperate and loyal, modest and cautious,
Orders march with trust and integrity.
Filial piety and harmony array the ranks,
The demonic forces surrender at a single strike.*

*The blind excel in hearing,
The deaf excel in sight.
Cutting off profit at its source,
Deploy tenfold armies;
Repeating reflection day and night,
Deploy ten thousandfold armies.*

**Cui Minggong said:**
*'The blind hear and the deaf see—
This is due to their singular focus,
Thus they are called skilled.*
*But if one can concentrate with unwavering sincerity,
And act with precise timing,
All endeavors shall be fully rewarded.
Moreover, if one can ponder deeply,
Reflecting day and night,
The benefits gained exceed ordinary wisdom ten thousandfold.'"

Qi and blood merge, and the elixir depends on lead and mercury.*

*The heart arises from things, yet perishes through things—its opportunity lies in the eyes.

*The critical moment of life and death lies in things,

*Men of virtue/Way do not let the heart arise in vain,

The vulgar and ignorant covet all things to enrich themselves,

This is how the heart arises from things and perishes through things.*

The Old Sage Ge Xianweng said:
*Knowing contentment brings no shame,

Adding to the allure of myriad things;
All because the eyes perceive, and the heart responds—

The Master Cui Minggong said:
*Those whose opportunity lies in the eyes must guard their vision,

Cui Minggong sang in *Lin Jiang Xian*:
*The heart stirs from the sight of things,

Cherish their households, secure their nations, and cultivate their bodies.

Awakening to the opportunity in the eyes,
Both heart and vision become clear.

To give without demanding repayment,

Yin and yang fermented, ascending to the elixir of immortality—

Follow the natural process, refining and shaping into form,

A single grain of elixir ensures eternal life.

If military orders are trusted and executed according to law,

A thousand worries fail to move them,
And seeking death, they cannot find it—
For the path to eternal life lies here.

Master Ge [Xianweng] extolled:
Few know the Gate of Life and the Door of Death,
Yet their operation lies within the trigrams **Kàn** and **Lí**.
When the two **Bā** are consumed, the yang qi grows strong;
At the three **Yīn** and three **Yáng**, the essence is refined.
Master Zhang [Zifang]’s *White Crane’s Son* states:
If one seeks the Dao/Way of immortality,
First, one must recognize the primordial root.

For the mind gives rise to scattered spirit,
And when the worldly attachments vanish, wisdom returns clear.
The heavens and earth serve as crucible and furnace,
While yin and yang act as fuel and flame.
Refined into the supreme elixir,
The work complete—one departs to meet the True.

Virtue/power born of harm,
Harm born of virtue/power.

Master Zhōnglí [Zhenren] said:
Virtue/power is the source of harm,
Harm is the current of virtue/power.

Master Lǚ [Zhenren] said:
The fundamental cause is virtue/power born of qi,
Yet failing to preserve the innate purity—
Drifting in the river of love,
Carried by the tides of desire—
This is virtue/power yielding harm,
Harm arising from virtue/power.

Master Xǔ [Zhenren] extolled:
Virtue/power born of qi has no intrinsic origin,
Yet harm arises when virtue/power is applied without reason.
Guarding the beginning with diligence,
Refining the elixir to perfection—
Even spirits are astonished.
Master Chìsōngzǐ’s *Lín Jiāng Xiān* states:
To return with sincerity is to love the spring,
Yet to cling endlessly is to recognize this as virtue/power.
Who knows that harm still grows within virtue/power?
When desire fades, virtue/power naturally perishes,
And with virtue/power gone, harm has no foundation.
Offspring stems from virtue/power’s cause,
Yet excessive virtue/power harms one’s form.
Those who refine virtue/power’s qi nurture a precious treasure—
Thirty-six transformations fulfilled,
Paying homage to the Jade Sovereign’s Cup.

The foolish see the heavens and earth’s patterns as sacred teachings,
I see the world’s timely shifts as wise revelations.
Master Zhang [Zifang] said:
Celestial patterns are the sun, moon, stars, and constellations—
Lightning, rain, wind, and clouds.
Earthly patterns are mountains, seas, metals, and stones—
Grasses, trees, scales, and feathers.
The foolish delight in auspicious stars, clouds of blessing,
Pure winds and sweet dews,
Or drink from the wine-springs and feast on rare grains,
Or behold the phoenix, deer, and immortal fungi—
All these they take as joy.
Yet when they see eclipses,
Seasons out of order,
Ominous comets and pestilential vapors,
Floods and droughts, locust plagues,
Sudden rains and violent winds,
Heavens dark and earth trembling—
They are seized with fear,
Dreading calamity may strike them.
Observing these celestial and terrestrial patterns,
They believe them to be lessons of caution,
Warnings to reflect and refine—
Thus, they ascend from the common to the sage,
And are called the *Patterned Sage*.

Master Liǔ Hǎichán said:
As the Yellow Emperor [Huangdi] composed the *Yīn Fú* [Scripture],
He first raised the foolish who saw the heavens and earth’s patterns as sacred teachings,
Then humbly declared: “I see the world’s timely shifts as wise revelations,
Meaning that what follows comes first.”

Master Xǔ [Zhenren] said:
The *Patterned Sage* of timely shifts refers to human affairs—
One need not gaze upon celestial omens,
But must always follow the Dao/Way in harmony with the times,
And even if disasters arise, they will not harm.

Master Chìsōngzǐ said:
Order belongs to the virtuous,
Chaos to the unworthy.
Embodying the heavens and conforming to the Dao/Way,
Adjusting to the seasons and aligning with the times—
With this refined understanding,
All worldly dualities dissolve into pure yang,
And the True Dao/Way is complete.

Master Zhōnglí [Zhenren] extolled:
Though celestial omens are lofty and profound,
They reveal auspicious and inauspicious signs—
Even the foolish, when enlightened,
Reflect and refine with diligence,
And thus have no cause for worry.
Fortune and misfortune are self-summoned,
Yet by observing the world’s shifts,
One discerns the rise and fall of all things.
Seizing the moment with virtue/power,
And always acting with benevolence—
Calamities and misfortunes are forever banished.

The *Yīn Fú* [Scripture]’s meaning is simple yet profound,
Its words subtle, its essence dense—
It guides the lost and enlightens the ignorant.
Its radiant light spreads far,
Illuminating the darkest paths.
Holding fast to the One, the elixir is perfected—
The realm grows rich, the people secure and tranquil,
The spirits rejoice in purity.
Strengthened armies prevail,
Pure yang refined—
One strides into the Mysterious Metropolis [Xuan Du].
The *Yīn Fú* [Scripture] of the Yellow Emperor concludes.」
